content:
- 6 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
and the National Shigella Centres. It should be emphasized, however, that the immediate outlook and preoccupations of the International Centres are somewhat different from those of the National Centres, in that the International Centres, as at present constituted, concentrate on the taxonomic component, (a), of their two-fold purpose, while The National Centres are immediately concerned not only with this aspect but also with component (b), namely, the epidemiological and public health implications of their laboratory studies. The International Centres' taxonomic studies, (a), are of a complex technical nature and must be carried out by specialized personnel within the limited circumference of a microbiological science, without any immediate epidemiological orientation to those studies. That is to say, their microbiological and taxonomic studies must be of the highest competence at the purely laboratory level, and any criticism that such work is too academic to justify direct support by WHO is answerable by the contention that microbiological and taxonomic studies form part of the essential raw material for epidemiological studies, and the better the quality of the raw material the more refined and the more serviceable the final product will be.
The functions and working relationships of the International Centres with the National Centres may perhaps be further clarified as follows, Suppose an outbreak of dysentery or food poisoning to occur in a particular country. Appropriate units of the country's health services, together with its National Shigella or Salmonella Centre, would then be responsible for isolating the causative organism and identifying it as far as they are able to do so. In making this identification the National Centre would be assisted by materials (sera and bacterial cultures) and advice from the International Centre; and if the organism is of a rare or anomalous type it would be despatched to the International Centre for identification. As for the epidemiological and public health aspects of the outbreak, it would, of course, again be the responsibility of the country's own health services to carry out the necessary investigations and action, but in the execution of those particular functions the National Centre might receive less direct assistance from the International Centre than . it would in the matter of identifying the organisms concerned. This is necessarily so not only because the International Centre is less immediately preoccupied with epidemiological problems than is the National Centre, but also because the detailed circumstances connected with an outbreak would, of course, be immediately accessible to the health authority of the country in a way which could not be possible to the
國史饭 Academia Historica
